insights.description: Although continued urbanization in China will drive commodity prices in the near term, the engine for the future will be growing urbanization in South-East Asia and India.

Despite tremendous growth in many areas, China is still lacking in the service industry, especially in healthcare. The challenge is to provide services capable of handling the rising demand brought upon by demographic change. While there is no existing safety net, there has been a lot of social reform since 2012.

People living in China are comfortable with a slowdown in growth, but overseas a 2% drop is considered dramatic. More information and transparency on the part of Chinese regulators is needed to address this perception gap.

title: 139 - New Energy Sources with the European Research Council

insights.description: Recent solar-cell research has found that nanowires can absorb more light when placed vertically – seemingly drawing energy from all around them and generating electrical power. Light-concentration conditions such as this cause solar cells to become more efficient.

Nuclear fusion is considered to be clean (no emissions) and safe (easy to halt the fusion reaction). But whether it will become a new source of global energy depends on the progress of new technologies still being developed. There are two challenges: the stability of the plasma inside power plants and how to extract tritium and heat from the reactors.

description:
How is machine learning transforming health and healthcare? 

Discover and debate in the IdeasLab: 
Idea 1: Using machine learning to predict neuro-degenerative disease
Idea 2: Smart devices will be the doctors of tomorrow
Idea 3: Machine learning for hospitals and health insurers 
Idea 4: Predictive analytics to stop outbreaks becoming epidemics 

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English and Mandarin Chinese<i>

<i>This session is filmed.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Machine Learning for Health with Carnegie Mellon University
title: 58 - Machine Learning for Health with Carnegie Mellon University

insights.description: Soon, stress-induced diseases may be prevented by identifying with greater certainty the areas of the brain affected by stress. Data-driven discovery will help the transition from descriptive research to diagnostic and preventive clinical applications of brain-mapping techniques.

Machine-learning tools have the ability to incorporate multiple types and large data sets of brain scans to analyse large and complex datasets. They can can also incorporate related sources and help reduce uncertainty in the design of clinical interventions.

Smart and wearable devices have incorporated numerous monitors – from voice recognition to geographical positioning to light sensors. This will open up avenues in healthcare through the search for and analysis of multiple correlated indicators and markers.

The level and intensity of social interactions has an effect on health. Mapping and understanding social interactions, and combining this data with health indicators will offer a more comprehensive view of individual health profiles. Smart devices and the use of machine learning will allow the exploration of seemingly unrelated issues.

NELL, a computer at Carnegie Mellon University, is learning on its own - it has been  continuously reading the World Wide Web for 5 years. With an increasing availability of processing capacity and of algorithms to improve information quality, machine self-learning will disrupt the artificial intelligence field.

Privacy issues make a single database of medical information unfeasible. Design and management of distributed systems will address confidentiality concerns while delivering high-quality information about individuals on demand.

Machine learning is advancing to correlate multiple external sources. Tracking behaviour of  a single individual is not enough to see a pattern. But an ecosystem approach (e.g., combining data from emergency-room visits with sales data of a given product at pharmacies) can help detect epidemic patterns.

insights.description: Paddy fields help to regulate floodwater and replenish groundwater. Other benefits include beautifying the environment, purifying water, regulating the temperature and generating oxygen. Overpopulation of cities is causing neglect of paddy fields, producing landslides and floods.

Architecture projects in megacities will allow citizens to produce their own food and even make a profit from their efforts. This will reduce the need to import food from abroad. New architecture can help build local economies through such options as fungiculture (mushroom farming), aquaculture or hydroponics, with the ability to process and market products locally. This could improve food security and mitigate the effects of overpopulation.
Global food waste is the third top CO2 emitter after US and China, and about one-third of all food that is produced is not eaten.
Some biochemical reactions can affect food components to increase its nutritional value and extend its shelf life. “Reuse, reduce and recycle” is also applicable for food products.

Free trade plays an important role in guaranteeing food security. Countries with a competitive advantage should be able to feed the world. However, some controversy exists due to national security concerns and the cost and environmental impact of water, which is usually distorted by subsidies.

insights.description: Unilever CEO Paul Polman pointed out that expectations around the Paris climate conference should be managed. COP21 is not about 2 degrees Celsius; several countries have already committed to reducing emissions – cutting global emissions by up to 40% – and more are expected to commit. That, in combination with a mechanism for continued improvement, could just lead to the strongest climate agreement ever.

China is one of the first countries where we can see that growth is slowing because it is hitting planetary boundaries. It hosts 22% of the world's population and only 7% of arable land. With land and water degrading fast, the country has no choice but to be serious about environmental sustainability. There are three things to focus on: (1) sustainable urbanisation (about 300 plans already in process); (2) agriculture and land use; (3) renewable energy ($2.5 trillion will have to be invested in the next decades)

Non-fossil sources of energy account for 10% of China's energy use. This is growing at about 5% a year. China's growth in renewable energy use accounts for one-third of the global growth figure. China accounts for one-third of the world total of investment in renewables and one-quarter of R&D. So, despite challenges, e.g. solar and wind are not able to enter the main grid in certain places and so a lot of renewable energy is wasted, renewable energy use is gaining pace in China.

PV panel prices are now one-eighth of what they had been. Solar prices are expected to drop with technological advances and scale and to reach parity with coal by 2025. This should mean that, by then, solar would be able to survive without subsidies.

COP21 is unlikely to achieve a global framework agreement that would be in line with limiting global warming to a 2C rise. Given the commitments already made (from some 50 countries – accounting for about 65% of global emissions – all commitment submissions have to be made by 1 October) and current expectations, a limit of 3.5C is possible – better than the expected 4C. But, if COP21 succeeds, this will still be the best-ever global climate change agreement forged.

description:

Discover and debate in the IdeasLab:
Idea 1: A power plant that fits in your pocket
Idea 2: The therapeutic power of snail venom
Idea 3: Microbe-powered machines
Idea 4: Blood transfusions to stop cognitive decline

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English and Mandarin Chinese<i>

<i>This session is filmed.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Unexpected Discoveries with Nature
title: 31 - Unexpected Discoveries with Nature

insights.description: Imagine charging a mobile phone using energy from the human body. Inspired by nature, scientists are working with piezoelectric materials to develop flexible electrodes that can withstand extreme mechanical environments. If these materials are interwoven into textiles such as shoes or clothing, it would be possible to capture energy from movement.

Drugs used to treat cancer that are currently on the market do not discriminate between healthy cells and cancerous cells; they destroy everything in their path. What if we had a treatment option that was able to distinguish and control the malfunctioning cells? Scientists have discovered a Tv1 peptide in cone snail venom that may be capable of manipulating signals that would “turn-off” cancer cells and prevent them from multiplying.

Did you know that energy can be harvested from evaporation? Bacterial spores respond to climate change by expanding and contracting like a sponge. Scientists have found a way to capture this energy by gluing spores to a special material that acts as a muscle when applied to water. These spores are 2,000 times stronger than human muscles and could potentially be used to lift heavy objects or apply strong force.
Can ageing be reversed? Can cognitive function be restored? Recent parabiosis studies with mice have found that if you reintroduce young blood into older specimens, cognitive function improves.

description:
The aim of this session is to explore how the public sector can get industry more engaged in basic research and science education.

On the agenda:
- Funding scientific innovation
- Partnering across sectors and industries
- Building the next generation of scientists 

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

title: 70 - Partnering for Science

insights.description: 3 stakeholder groups are key to bridging the  gaps between academia and industry: (1) Strong leaders, who can play decisive roles in bridging these gaps; (2) Adapted policy-making, would allow more meaningful engagement and productive ways to get around these gaps; (3) Agencies that with specific roles, e.g. the Agency for science, tech and research (ASTAR), in Singapore

From tech development to market, joint efforts are needed to improve the efficiency of scientific research. In academia, structure of knowledge provided could be improved. The UNESCO catalogue, for example, outlines thousands of disciplines, but the logic and organization of this are not clear. Investment will be more efficient if new planning of disciplines is introduced and research becomes more rational.

There are interesting examples of collaboration catalysts between industry and academia, like the AMP (accelerating medicines partnership) - bringing together scientists from pharma companies and from academia. The companies pay for half of the cost and the data is open and available. This works because pharma want to be at the table and build relationships with the research scientists.

Additionally, competition from the New Development Bank and the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank is likely to make existing multilateral institutions more efficient and outcome-oriented.

Among the reasons for China’s infrastructure investments in neighbouring countries are its massive production surplus in the domestic economy and the build-up of significant construction capacity, which need to be put to productive use. China also recognizes that peace and stability in the neighbourhood requires economic development in those regions.

description:
What will it take for China's entrepreneurs to build truly global businesses and brands?

Dimensions to be addressed:
- Advancing "one belt, one road" and other initiatives
- Overcoming trade and market access challenges
- Building "glo-cal" brand reputation and trust

This session was developed in partnership with Phoenix Television and Dalian Radio & Television Station. 

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions

title: 107 - The Global Rise of China's Entrepreneurs

insights.description: According to an APCO survey, 90% of the people in the US couldn’t name more than one Chinese brand. The biggest challenge for Chinese enterprise to rise globally is market entry. Another is to invest in branding, or ROR  on reputation. Chinese companies need to think about the face of their brand as they go abroad.

Chinese brands have become stronger in the past 20 years and continue to do so. However, as Chinese companies expand their businesses into other countries, they need to understand and respect local culture in order to win trust from the local community.

In the past 30 years, the Chinese market has been fully globalized by foreign investment. In the next 20 years, the global economy will be "Chinalized". The challenges for Chinese companies, however, are: lack of global vision, lack of global value and lack of global resource integration. Chinese entrepreneurs need to broaden their vision and need to adopt globalized enterprise governance.

There are more than 100 Chinese companies on the Fortune 500 list; however, there is barely any on the top global 100 brands list. This shows that Chinese companies need to pay more attention to brand building. Chinese companies also need to be more strategic about going global. They should not just follow other company’s models; they need to prepare themselves and think of their own strategy.

Innovation needs to initiate from a variety of dreams, not for the sake of making money. China emphasizes "building a strong national brand" too much. Chinese companies going global need to truly broaden their vision, even forget the brand is Chinese; they need to bring in humanity factors, value factors and answer questions of purpose first, so that the brand can  become a truly global brand that drives social progress and innovation.

insights.description: In China there are many business founders who are passionate – but not clear – about what they want to achieve. Sometimes they may feel they have succeeded and can retire, but they need to be shown how to appreciate the social value their business is creating and continue.

Much of the discussion about disruption is related to consumption, but China is the world’s biggest manufacturer and changes in traditional manufacturing are as big as changes in consumption. This will significantly transform shop floors and production models in the coming years.

Consumption in China will grow by about $320 billion this year and half of it will come from online consumption. This is a much higher percentage than in other parts of the world and shows how much mobile devices and the internet has touched Chinese people’s lives.

description:
How do innovative businesses maintain their edge?

Dimensions to be addressed:
- Disrupting existing business models
- Fostering action and agile leadership
- Investing in growth and expansion

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: The Innovation Playbook
title: 4 - The Innovation Playbook

insights.description: Innovation requires keeping one’s feet in two places at once: it is important to find the right place to innovate while remaining empathetic to customers. Many companies spend most of their time optimizing existing assets for existing customers. But the real innovation challenge is finding new users for new technologies. The key to success is not fighting disrupting ideas, but building a new business around them.

Many companies do not realize that setting up an in-house group solely dedicated to innovation is the “kiss of death” for innovation. It is not possible to work on innovation; it is only possible to work on the innovation process. Innovation is not a thing, but a how. It is something that can only be glanced at in the rear-view mirror. The process should seek the collaboration of many different parts of the company, but should also be firmly driven from the top.

Most companies display two silos: innovation and operational. The operational silo contains the “antibodies” that protect the core businesses from the risks of innovation. Such protection standards must be present to ensure the company’s survival. But the silos themselves must be taken down. Companies must remove these barriers and ensure the two sides communicate and understand each other.

By 2020, the majority of the population will be formed by millennials. Large, traditional companies are not agile enough to innovate by themselves. They should tap into the resources, knowledge and skills of millennials to uncover innovative ideas and solutions.

Innovation is not a linear process. It is a learning process, conducted through collaboration. “Co-creation” is a better term for innovation. The co-creation process should be based on three core principles: very rapid experimentation, learning by doing and metrics-driven experience. Put ideas to work fast, experiment with it, and work with customers to see if these ideas are solving their problems.

description:
How should intellectual property systems adapt to an interconnected world?

Dimensions to be addressed:
- Role of intellectual property in the internet era
- Impact of big data on intellectual property rights services
- Implications for innovation and the upgrading of value chains

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is webcast live.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Intellectual Property in the Information Age
title: 93 - Intellectual Property in the Information Age

insights.description: Intellectual property has sometimes been characterized as an impediment to the information age, as it is seen as creating proprietary obstacles to open innovation and shared collaboration. Yet intellectual property might actually be a critical tool to help governments facilitate open innovation and shared collaboration.
As the information age continues to evolve, countries are constantly seeking new ways to export their knowledge and to become more global. Intellectual assets can actually help us keep pace.

Intellectual property is an extremely flexible instrument. What it does is to offer access to a marketable commodity. That’s how you get technology moving about, and how you get digital content moving about: you sell access.

There are many ways of using intellectual property. The 20th century way was exclusivity (we want it so we’ll keep it) but the digital age has brought new options, such as the Commons or Open Source. Our historical legacy is an intellectual property system that is national, while our economic and technological systems are global. The question is how we adapt intellectual property systems for global use.
Of the top 10 patents coming out of China, seven are from the information technology sector. Furthermore, in the patent application process 90% of patents are approved online.

Many of today's business models are contributed to by third parties. In this case it is hard to tell its value or who owns it. Is it the inventor, the founder or someone else? People create intellectual property every day, but have no idea how to protect it. We need to think about how it is shared and how to use it in a socially responsible way.

The task before us is to construct the global digital content marketplace and balance the capacity to exploit exclusivity with the opportunity to take advantage of the greatest digital culture we have had in recent times.

description:
Tissue engineer Mark Post shares how cultured meat technology can be a powerful alternative to mass meat production.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is filmed.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: The Meat Revolution
title: 48 - The Meat Revolution

insights.description: When people start to eat meat from different sources, the whole concept of meat will change. For example, fatty acids can be changed to Omega 3s, thereby enabling a positive impact not only on the environment, but also on health.

To bring the cost of cultured meat down from the current projected cost of $65 per kg, one option is to reuse all of the components in the production of the meat. This circular approach will not only improve the cost, but also reduce the strain on resources.

Growing cultured meat will require four things: efficiency, sustainability, mimicry and acceptability. If success is achieved in these areas, cultured meat will allow humans to continue consuming without the environmental impact.

Cultured meat will eliminate many ethical issues associated with the consumption of traditional meat, and will be the primary driver of its consumption. The challenge will be in aligning “man-made” meat with safety – if this can be overcome, there is tremendous potential.

description:
Discover new ways of visualizing and analysing big data with robotics expert Illah Nourbakhsh and remote sensing scientist Matthew Hansen.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is filmed.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Discovering Disruptive Change with Big Data
title: 2 - Discovering Disruptive Change with Big Data

insights.description: Progressive policies are critical for realizing the real promise of big data analytics. We need to be able to draw on large amounts of freely available datasets in order to develop truly transformative perspectives on the world, via Earth observation, for example.

Brazil is one of the only countries that slowed deforestation rates by some 70-80% over the past years and therefore made one of the largest contributions to the global reduction of greenhouse gas. Deforestation rates in other regions, particularly in Indonesia, have grown significantly in the same time frame.

Future generations will be flooded with data about all sorts of global phenomena. In order to realize the promise of big data, we need our children to become technologically fluent in data analysis and statistics.

description:
Discover how space technology allows real-time mapping of carbon emissions with NASA scientist David Crisp.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is filmed.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Fighting Emissions from Space
title: 19 - Fighting Emissions from Space

insights.description: NASA's Orbiting Carbon Observatory (OCO) measures carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere with a precision high enough to detect the origin and fate of greenhouse gas emissions.

There has been a 20% increase in atmospheric concentration of greenhouse gas since 1979. As only half of the carbon emitted stays in the atmosphere - the rest going to the oceans and other carbon sinks - it is important to understand processes that pull the CO2 out of the atmosphere.

description:
From classrooms to corporate labs, what are the most successful ways to incubate entrepreneurship? 

Dimensions to be addressed:
- Spotting scalable business models
- Devising robust funding mechanisms
- Strengthening leadership capacity

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English and Mandarin Chinese<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Incubating Entrepreneurship
title: 54 - Incubating Entrepreneurship

insights.description: Data in the United States shows that all new net jobs created were created by companies less than 5 years old.

Is entrepreneurship teachable?
Some skills important to an entrepreneur are teachable: technical skills, business skills, even managing skills. But for a certain high-impact type of entrepreneur, the one that really changes the world and revolutionizes sectors and markets, there is a type of energy or ambition that is not teachable, something that is related to a personal drive, They looks at something impossible and say I want to do it because it’s impossible, and impossible means less competition. These kinds of "skills" are hard to define and are not teachable.

In China, the government is making an effort to help create more companies by providing benefits and funding. China’s business climate has improved: an individual can now open a new business in under five days; 10 years ago, it would take half year.

We are trying to create this entrepreneurial ecosystem in Malaysia. My country has always been very efficient in production. But I see many companies from other countries that buy our products, repackage and sell for 10 times the price. It’s not only innovation in production, but also in marketing and entrepreneurship that are needed. That’s why we are trying to create this ecosystem in which entrepreneurs have this innovation mindset.

title: 68 - The Transformation of Finance

insights.description: Banks and financial services institutions can survive the challenges posed by technology by seeing themselves as data analytics firms and positioning themselves as technology companies with a "little bit of financial services on the side".
Technology is a liberating mechanism in the financial services sector. It offers opportunities in inclusive growth by giving access to those previously outside of the banking system.

Consumers were once willing to compromise security for cost. Today, they want better products, at a faster rate and at a cheaper price -- security, speed and affordability. One way technology can help match consumer needs is through “tokenization” to increase data security. With the amount of information flowing in, banks need to adapt their security mechanisms as if they were data analytics firms rather than as traditional financial services institutions.

description:
What trends and uncertainties are transforming the future of work?

Drivers of transformation:
- New manufacturing and service models
- Machine intelligence and robotics
- Tech-readiness and STEM education

This session is part of the Mapping Industry Transformation series.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English and Mandarin Chinese<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: The Transformation of the Workplace
title: 95 - The Transformation of the Workplace

insights.description: We are in the middle of a decade-long trend towards big data and automated decision-making. Many workflow processes will increasingly be subject to big-data analysis, enabling approaches such as “predictive/preemptive maintenance” of equipment and machinery. Every routine job in every industry could become semi-automated and subject to precise quantitative performance measurement.

Many emerging business models might involve offering machines and equipment as an entry point to using the data generated by them. We will need a workforce with the right skills to take advantage of this.

Pilot cases in Japan have shown that the use of machine-learning tools and tablets in the classroom can improve education outcomes. Human teachers inevitably standardize the way knowledge is communicated, whereas tablets allow adaptive learning at suitable levels of difficulty and challenge for students’ needs. Machine-automated grading may remove subjective human judgements. Teachers will increasingly become supervisors of artificial-intelligence tools.

Online labour markets, crowdsourcing and e-lancing platforms are creating flatter organizational structures and fluidity in organizational boundaries. Initially mostly advertising data entry and unskilled work, such platforms now increasingly involve advanced specialist skills as well. Through big data matching algorithms, artificial intelligence could bring together remote virtual teams more effectively than human resources managers.

60% of kids entering primary school today will work in job categories that don’t yet exist. Education systems need to be flexible, adaptable and focus on learning-how-to-learn. The idea of a one-time education providing people with a lifelong skillset is definitively a thing of the past.

title: 87 - Connecting the Unconnected

insights.description: In 2014, household internet penetration was at 79% on average in developed countries vs. only some 32% in developing countries. This indicates that improvement in connectivity can also increase the digital divide, which particularly affects people living in rural areas.

Most studies verify the positive impact of broadband penetration on GDP growth, which can vary from 0.25 to 1.38 % for every 10% gain in penetration. On GDP per capita, this  translates into an increase of approximately 0.8% and for unemployment rates, it generates a decrease of about 0.8%.

While prices for entry-level mobile broadband packages in developed countries average just 1-2% of monthly income, developing countries are facing significant higher costs, equal to 8-11.5% of monthly income. This mostly affects those living in extreme poverty and in rural areas. The solutions need to address both costs of services and devices as well as the willingness to pay for them.

Network operators are facing significant investment and operating costs as well as low monetization potential, challenging the financial viability of projects. These challenges are especially prevalent in rural areas with typically low average revenues per user. High costs spread over thinly populated areas with low income, causing significant coverage gaps within countries.

description:
How are business and policy entrepreneurs turning big data into better decisions?

Session objectives:
- Explore state of the art in big data analysis
- Understand the potential and pitfalls of data-driven decision-making
- Exchange best practices of using big data strategically

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English and Mandarin Chinese<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Know More, Do Better
title: 27 - Know More, Do Better

insights.description: We access massive written content through anindex, which is the foundation of a lot of searching engines. The development of data storage algorithms are for the first time leapfrogging the way we approach content. Today, there are big reading challenges in areas such as academic research, legal cases, etc. Obstacles to rolling out the data-driven approach are more often non-tech factors such as building in-house solutions and silos between departments.

Big data can help accelerate decision-making on hiring and evaluating performance in many ways. Predictive rather than reactive data will allow companies to act ahead of the curve on talent acquisition. Data can also help identify what motivates employees the most in large organizations with complex working environments. Tracking the value creation by the talent pool and providing insights on the Millennials are other ways to leverage data analytics.

According to a recent PwC survey, 53% of  respondents say they either don't understand data or don't use data at all. Causes for this vary: middle-level staff providing data to top management often lack understanding of what the executives really need; business and IT people don't connect; data is not sufficiently standardized;barriers to data flow exist between different departments, etc. One way to emphasize the importance of data is to reset Key Performance Indicators (KIPI), to promote a culture of leveraging data for decision-making. Establishing a department to focus on cultural transition and rally collective effort from different departments would help reduce resistance to data use.

In order to access valuable consumer data and improve the service experience, companies must build trust and awareness among the public when it comes to data ownership. Education will play a big role in this because we need to inform consumers about who they are online, who owns their data and how to understand the power of data. Meanwhile, we need to create incentives for consumers to share data, and give them opportunities to opt in or out.

How can cutting-edge science be applied in the natural world to open new frontiers in technology and engineering? 

Discover and debate in the IdeasLab:

Idea 2: Sequestering heavy metals in soil
Idea 3: Exploring renewables beyond tectonic complexity
Idea 4: Discovering agricultural applications from plant genetics

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English and Mandarin Chinese<i>

<i>This session is filmed.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Catalysing Nature-Based Technology with Peking University
title: 97 - Catalysing Nature-Based Technology with Peking University

insights.description: Soil is the skin of our planet and we are not looking after it. About 16% of the land is polluted with heavy metals, which reaches the food chain and is absorbed by our bodies.

One way to solve the problem of ground pollution is by collecting the affected soil and taking it somewhere else. In some places, polluted soil cannot be removed. One alternative is to use microorganisms and fungi to “clean” the soil. Fungi work with plants, changing the nature of the soil and feeding the plants. Pollutants can be sequestered in the soil by fungi and some toxic metals can even be used to remediate and improve the quality of the soil.

The global demand for energy is growing; at the same time, we are moving from a fossil fuel (oil and coal) economy to an economy based on renewable energy. Renewables are not enough; and natural gas can bridge the energy gap during the estimated 20-30 year transition to renewable energy sources. In addition, natural gas produces only half of the CO2 emitted by coal.
Transgenic food is very safe, with no reports to the contrary to date. RNA spray can be used produce plants that are resistant to plant viroids, insects and even fungal pathogens.

insights.description: Reuse Ewaste has become a significant way to protect the environment and promote sustainable development. The core elements involve creating effective modules, adjusting the diverse target  wastes and greening the whole life cycle from the beginning.

Hazardous materials found in e-waste contain heavy metals, such as mercury, lead, cadmium, as chemicals, such as chlorofluorocarbons or various flame retardants. But, e-waste also contains valuable materials, such as iron, copper, aluminium and plastics, and precious metals, such as gold, silver, platinum and palladium, all which can be recycled.

description:
Deep learning algorithms draw powerful insights from quantities of data typically beyond human comprehension. What if machine intelligence advances beyond the control of its creators?

Join an in-depth discussion that explores the possible, plausible and probable impacts of artificial intelligence.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is webcast live.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: What If: Machines Outsmart Us All?
title: 5 - What If: Machines Outsmart Us All?

insights.description: We face an immediate choice on autonomous weapons: a treaty with strong constraints or an arms race. The likely outcome of legalized autonomous weapons would be to put the lives of millions of people in the hands of anyone with $20 million to programme a drone. It shifts the power of mass death to non-state actors and increases the possibility of misuse and mistakes.

An audience poll found that more people would trust an AI doctor over a human one. But because machines still lack the “explainability” necessary to establish trust between a patient and doctor, robots are unlikely to eliminate the need for a family practitioner.

Is there an empathy economy? When humans lost jobs during the Industrial Revolution, they had to rely on their minds. But now that artificial intelligence is taking over in that department, it seems that empathy is the third thing humans can offer, after manual and mental labour. Jobs in social work and therapy may be the future, but they are low-paid.

Changes brought about by technological progress mean people will have multiple jobs throughout their lives. Smart policy would be to re-orient education towards more granular, just-in-time micro-learning, so that people can dip in and learn new skills quickly.

Are robots going to kill us all? Defence companies are already designing autonomous weapons that can track down and kill human targets. It's an issue that needs urgent attention: the UN has held three meetings to debate the legality of lethal autonomous robots in combat scenarios.

description:
From landing robots on comets to monitoring Earth's vital signs, explore how space technologies are enabling us to scale the Universe and safeguard humanity’s place within it.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is webcast live.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Bringing Space Down to Earth
title: 102 - Bringing Space Down to Earth

insights.description: For the first time ever, scientists have been able to study a comet up close and even landed the Rosetta space craft on the 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimko comet last year. So far, scientists have found organic molecules in samples of the comet that have never been seen outside of Earth. Studying our solar system and comets in particular allows researchers to look back at the beginning of the solar system’s formation and Earth as it cooled about 3.5 billion years ago. As comets carry the necessary ingredients for the formation of life, the collision of a comet into planets like ours could create the necessary conditions for the genesis of life.

The Kepler mission has so far found over 5,000 planets; it is estimated that, for every star similar to ours, there is on average one habitable planet orbiting it. Within a decade, most nearby stars will have been assessed for habitable planets with the help of two missions: TESS by NASA and Plato by ESA. By analysing the light as it passes through the atmosphere of a planet, scientists can deduce its chemical composition and gauge how likely the planet is to contain the necessary ingredients to support life. More-powerful telescopes being deployed in the coming years will provide an even closer look at the formation of the universe and help answer long-held questions.

Technology that is used for space exploration can also help with today’s pressing global challenges. Satellites, and constellations of satellites from companies such as DigitalGlobe, flying in orbit around Earth at 7.8 km/s, are examining and making digital imagery of every corner of the planet. In a disaster, the ability to direct rescuers to destroyed homes by accurately mapping roads that are still functioning is one way satellites can help. Getting real-time images of forest fires and where they originate is another example.

Continued investment in space exploration and astronomy is important because they help drive technological innovation; many of the technology benefits we now enjoy come from the learning acquired from space programmes over the last 50 years. Another positive by-product of space exploration is international collaboration. As in other scientific fields, research and the quest for knowledge know no geographical, political or cultural bounds. Motivation for the next generation to study sciences and maths is another important reason.

description:
New genome-editing techniques promise to revolutionize healthcare, while some researchers hope to take the technology even further. What if genetic modification of human embryos becomes cheap, easy and ubiquitous?

Join an in-depth discussion that explores the possible, plausible, and probable impacts of genetically modifying human embryos.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is webcast live.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: What If: Anyone Can Edit the Human Genome?
title: 150 - What If: Anyone Can Edit the Human Genome?

insights.description: In early 2015, the UK government, after an extensive public consultation and debate, approved the transfer of mitochondria to human eggs whose own mitochondria were defective. In April 2015, Chinese researchers went further, using a technique known as CRISPR/Cas9. While, in this instance, researchers used non-viable embryos unsuccessfully to attempt to treat a hereditary disease called beta thalassaemia, the researchers were judged to have crossed a line, having gone ahead without national consultation on safety or ethical issues.

Two main factors hold back the development of gene editing: the first is delivery, in particular how to ensure delivery of the DNA through the cell membrane into the nucleus: at the moment, a number of delivery strategies and technologies have been attempted. The other more significant challenge is specificity: we do not know what the ‘off-target’ impact of DNA is once it is in the cell, for example how it can affect other areas of the genome. This can be deleterious not only for the individual but future generations and therefore for humanity itself.

Genome editing has the potential to relieve great pain and suffering, but it is right to be worried. Despite its potential for the treatment of hereditary disease, gene editing comes with a host of risks. Aside from unforeseen consequences, governments could use gene editing for eugenics through coercion. At the individual level, risks include reinforced inequality between those who can afford it and those who can’t, and too many people selecting ‘fashionable’ genes that could lead to biodiversity loss, thereby reducing resistance to disease across the population.

While the research in China this year demonstrated that we are still some way off being able to edit the genome successfully, it also proved that progress is much faster than anyone expected. To make sure that there is a thorough and transparent debate on ethics and regulation of genome technologies, dialogue on why and in what circumstances lines might be crossed must start now, and must not be restricted to the scientific community.

Regulation and oversight on genome technologies must be led internationally and engage all stakeholders. The process leading up to the UK’s approval of mitochondria transfer is already being held up as a best practice example, in that it debated the ethics with the Huffield Ethics Council and the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA), a regulator concerned with the safety risks of the technology. Both agencies conducted public consultation, which was ratified in the Houses of Commons and Lords. For such schemes to work on an international level, oversight and leadership from either a dedicated or existing international organization is called for.

In the US, the issue of gene editing is contentious and divisive, while other countries lack a culture of openness in decision-making. Ethicists and regulators can play a role here, helping as trusted organizations steer the discussion towards a democratic deliberation on whether or not the technology can serve humankind. This is a more positive role than is commonly understood, as, by rejecting some technologies, resources are freed up for other treatments that have greater potential benefits.

insights.description: Consumers are increasingly relying on devices to monitor their health. While vast amounts of information will be generated from these devices, data compatibility and security when storing and sharing this information will be a challenge. A collaborative multistakeholder approach will be needed to find a solution on data ownership and security.

Access to health data is becoming more available due to the increasing accessibility and affordability of health-related technologies, i.e. large, costly health-related machines are increasingly becoming user friendly and readily available to individuals at affordable prices. Educating device users on interpreting personal data within the right context will be key to ensure a most effective use of the information provided by these devices.

Hyperconnectivity in the field of healthcare is empowering individuals by providing them with personal health records and including them more in the decision-making process for their own health outcome. By empowering the consumer, however, the healthcare industry will face a turbulent transition from such traditional practices as data privacy.

insights.description: The price of commodities and China's slowdown have had a big impact on countries like Brazil. "Yes, Brazil is worried about China's slowdown." - Marcos Vinicius de Souza, Secretary of Innovation, MDIC, Brazil

States in India have a much bigger role to play in the development planning of the whole country. Telangana state is quite young and has a very good industrial policy and also benefits from India’s huge, stable and growing market. - Kalvakuntla Chandrashekar Rao, Chief Minister of Telangana

One remedy for stagnating economies is to create quick success stories to bring confidence to the country and attract investors. Huajian Group, which employs 25,000 workers in China, expects to be able to provide about 30,000 jobs in Addis Ababa by 2022.

Brazil is changing its industrial policy to one that is more open and international. The government is trying to support companies to look abroad, not only in selling but also in establishing real cooperation with other countries (innovation and R&D projects). Brazil reported a 91% increase in international development cooperation from 2009 to 2010. The number of new technical cooperation projects initiated by Brazil rose from 23 in 2003 to 413 in 2009.
1.4 billion people are moving, peacefully, to mid-income countries – a huge demand that represents an opportunity for emerging markets.

The number of people living in poverty in China has decreased by 439 million, from 689 million in 1990 to 250 million in 2011. China has made great contributions to global poverty reduction efforts. The country will become a high-income country and engage in capital-intensive industries. South East Asia will not be able to absorb this job demand, but Africa, with a population of 1.2 billion, could fill the gap
Cooperation between Malawi and China has increased and the relationship has gone beyond trade to skills transfer, investment partnership with universities, medical training and call-centre training.

According to Marcos Vinicius de Souza, Secretary of Innovation, MDIC, Brazil: Emerging markets are not at a crossroads; they will continue to move the economy. The current situation is merely a “bump on the road”.
Three billion people are expected to enter the middle-class ranks by 2050. Almost all of them are coming from emerging markets. – HSBC report

insights.description: Many technology companies involved in finance developed in Silicon Valley are often country-centric. They rely on information from credit bureaus and single currencies. For financial technology to expand to developing markets, they need to find ways to work around these constraints.

Innovations in digital finance over the last five years have been on the consumer-facing end (mobile banking apps, etc). The future of digital finance will depend on automation and machine intelligence in the back-end of banking.

Automation will ultimately not kill finance jobs because it will always require some offline approaches. While some processes can be simplified and standardized through the Internet, some complicated products like insurance and tax planning will always require a service-oriented, human approach.

With the rapid pace of change in the world of digital finance, regulators are being challenged. How can they support innovation in this field while still creating necessary stabalization? The future may be in regulators regulating financial activities rather than financial institutions, as the lines between financial firms and non-financial firms will begin to blur.

insights.description: One of the objectives for regulators is to separate new technologies like drones from old technology like aircraft, to ensure a safe and secure operating environment. Drones can connect remote areas or can be deployed in large congested cities, offering a new mode of transportation. As drones are being used increasingly for a range of non-military applications, governments, such as in Switzerland, are addressing the issue from a regulatory aspect.

To ensure safety, more work is needed to define an international safety framework. However, today there are use cases such as in agriculture and industrial inspection, where humans are not at risk and benefits are tangible.

insights.description: Traditional retail grows about one-and-a-half times GDP; online commerce within countries is growing at about four times GDP; and cross-border e-commerce is growing about seven times GDP. This represents an opportunity for small and medium-sized enterprises to expand their customer base nationally and across the world.

The World Health Organization estimates that sales of medicines that are counterfeit, contaminated or otherwise illegal total $430 billion a year. Products are identified through labels and packaging, but are easy to fake. Digital economy allows us to address this issue by, for example, directly marking food, medicine and other goods with dust-particle sized and edible microtags for authentication.

Digital technology will have a $14 trillion impact on the global economy by 2030. We are at very early stages of this shift, and countries and companies will need to reshape themselves to face that disruption.

Retail traditionally has been local, but now retailers are able to reach consumers around the world. There are about $1.8 trillion of unsold inventory in the US, which represents a big opportunity with digital trade to better align supply and demand.

description:
Leaps in brain research have propelled the development of brain interface technologies from prosthetics to attention-powered vehicles, while neuroscientific evidence is increasingly entering courtrooms. What if technologies for reading thoughts, memories and cognitive ability become commonplace?

Join an in-depth discussion that explores the possible, plausible, and probable impacts of advanced neural engineering.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is webcast live. <i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: What If: Your Mind Can Be Read?
title: 61 - What If: Your Mind Can Be Read?

insights.description: We're already sharing lots of information about our behaviour online for marketing purposes, but not for health purposes. One of the best bio-markers of the mental state of someone on the verge of neuropsychosis is their online search history (or that of their parents). This, along with speech detection, is an effective precursor to in-person interview.

Leveraging technology can help in the diagnosis and treatment of mental disorders and addressing chronic non-communicable diseases in cases where we do not have the tools available to treat them. These technologies could lead to rapid diagnosis and change the trajectory of brain and mind development.

In neuroscience, the concern is not what we can see, but who has access to this information about ourselves. We can access brain waves in ways we couldn’t before, and this will change the relationship we have with our doctors and other health providers.

title: 122 - Decoding Cancer

insights.description: Cancer results from DNA “spelling” mistakes. CRISPR-CAS9 can edit the genes and repair such mistakes. Genome editing can also train T-cells to do their job better, engineering more specialized versions of the cells.
With cancer, it doesn’t really matter which organ gets hit; what matters is the type of mutation. Cancer is a disease of the DNA and results from replication spelling mistakes.

Cancer cells escape the immune system and continue to grow. As they mutate, it takes more than one drug to combat the first and then the second variant. This requires a combination of therapies, which is our challenge for the next five decades.

insights.description: Many studies document the tangible benefits of having a diverse team. Diverse non-expert teams regularly beat homogenous expert groups in complex reasoning tasks, with increased performance particularly linked to gender balance.

Women will account for US$ 5 trillion of additional consumer spending over the next five years and control 75% of the world’s disposable income by 2028. As a market, women are bigger than China and India taken together.

Women account for 40% of engineering jobs in China, 20-30% in the West and only 10% in Japan. We need to understand the talent pipeline, find out where it is that we lose women, and create clear accountability.
The app economy professionalizes housework tasks, giving them greater recognition and an economic value. This allows for a more fluid division of labour in the household.

description:
From cinemas to online streaming, how is China shaping the future of media and entertainment?

Dimensions to be addressed:
- Developing creative talent
- Strengthening China's brand
- Fostering global partnerships

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is webcast live. <i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: China's Dream Factory
title: 148 - China's Dream Factory

insights.description: While China is the largest consuming country in terms of media entertainment, its own strength lies in core technologies and content licencing. The year 2015 can be seen as a tipping point in China`s advancement, from content licencing and changes in its value proposition and pricing models, towards a more content-oriented production mode.

Due to the lack of legal protection and no concrete guidelines on purchasing content, the Chinese media and entertainment industry needs to learn from foreign producers to gain a deeper understanding of processes and knowledge. In addition, an enabling legal environment will be important in developing Chinese content and marketing it abroad. In this regard, the internet offers a more promising and more customizable option than traditional cinema.

While Hollywood remains the dominant force within the global entertainment industry, China`s local talent market and production conditions are also favourable. What the Chinese market lacks is the opportunity to tell Chinese stories, which would constitute the real meaning of going global for China`s entertainment industry.

China wants to push its soft power within the media and entertainment industry, but it is difficult because of language and cultural barriers, and because of an explicit demand for Western content in its domestic market.

Going global is an appealing prospect for China, and technological improvements to infrastructure and broadband development will play a major role in that move. This will go hand in hand with two other strategies: China will need to create content relevant to the Western customer, and recruit back the talented and experienced industry professionals who left for other countries.

description:
How are advances in synthetic biology paving the way for novel products and new industries?

Discover and debate in the IdeasLab:
Idea 1: Reconstructing biology to create designer cells
Idea 2: Hacking exotic organisms and putting them to work
Idea 3: Scaling synthetic biology from lab to market
Idea 4: Programming and controlling life

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English and Mandarin Chinese<i>

<i>This session is filmed.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: The Revolution in Synthetic Biology with Imperial College London
title: 128 - The Revolution in Synthetic Biology with Imperial College London

insights.description: Scaling up from something that works in an individual test tube to working in an industrial bioreactor is a major hurdle to overcome in the chemicals industry; discovery does not equal delivery. And on the larger scale, the concentration and amount of byproducts causes problems.

Technology, including synthetic biology, is agnostic. It is the user's intentions that decide whether its use is good/beneficial or bad. We should aim to manage technology in a way that leads to a better society.
Metabolic pathways and synthetic biology paths can be optimized digitally and from a laptop. To really optimize, it is necessary to capture feedback - this is the necessary part of the reaction.

We can slow bio-reactions to try to optimize and catalyse, mitigating the changing environment; but we don't know when the cell is “unhappy”. We can determine this by assessing it with bio-sensors, and then adapt the environment.

In terms of scaling-up, designing and optimizing a bio-reaction, the process is like a franchise: using the framework of the overall concept and depending on the output and conditions, the right cell can be matched to produce the right product.

Funding long-term investment in technology that is easily bootlegged has clear obstacles and some solutions. Mechanisms already exist to protect intellectual property. The issue is comparable to software and medications, where you need to innovate to stay ahead. There is a good comparison with the music industry: some will fund to have first-mover advantage, and some will try to add labels or "kill switches" to prevent theft. Processes for the public good will be funded with different intentions and issue to those who invest purely for money generation.

insights.description: 99% of our human genome is the same from human to human, but we only share 10% of our microbiomes.
How bad a certain food is for your body depends on your microbiome.
How a body metabolizes depends completely on its microbiome and not on the human genome.
Our underlying biological mechanisms are dynamic, which means that a change in diet and lifestyle will be felt quickly by the body.

If your friends are obese, you are 45% more likely to be obese. Social networks and support structures impact behaviour.
Depression occurs clinically to 20% of people sometime over their lifetime. Solutions must be targeted as widely as possible.

description:
What trends and uncertainties are shaping the future of consumer and retail industries in China?

Drivers of transformation:
- Shifting consumption patterns in the digital age
- Market demands of the post-90s generation
- Convergence of offline and online retailing models

This session is part of the Mapping Industry Transformation series.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English and Mandarin Chinese<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: The Transformation of China's Consumer Industries
title: 8 - The Transformation of China's Consumer Industries

insights.description: Mobile commerce in China accounts for almost 50% of digital transaction volume in China. Those companies whose digital commerce strategies extend into mobile will be better poised to win in the long term.

Chinese consumers are wealthier than they were two to three decades ago. But with this wealth comes unhealthy lifestyles, more stress and poor nutrition. Consumers are trying to stay healthy, but obesity is spreading, as is cardiovascular disease. Food and beverage companies, in particular, must help Chinese consumers by investing in delivery healthier food and beverage options and leveraging digital platforms to educate consumers so they can make informed choices.

The “internet-plus” age is transforming industry. In China, those born after the 1990s have unique personalities and profiles; these digital natives have different shopping habits and mindsets from earlier generations. To compete, companies must adopt new business models and ways to engage and educate consumers.

More than 80% of deaths in China are attributed to chronic disease, and cardiovascular problems affect about 300 million Chinese people. As a result, Chinese consumers are nutrition-oriented. Companies must deliver solutions that help consumers lead healthier, happier lifestyles.

Although online shopping is on the rise in China, brick and mortar retail still plays an important role. Sixty-one percent of Chinese consumers say that the physical shopping experience is still enjoyable. Thirty-four percent want to see, touch and try before they actually purchase the product. Online will not take over offline; both are important to deliver a differentiated customer experience.

Twenty-five percent of global consumers (approximately 1 billion people) order products online. In 2014, the total online retail sales in China accounted for 11% of its entire retail purchases, and this percentage will only increase. The convergence between online and offline is transforming the industry in unprecedented ways. E-commerce is not just a sales channel; it’s a reinvention of business models.

Digital is allowing companies to gain completely new insights about their consumers. For example, by monitoring online behaviour, Nestlé learned that the prime time for mothers to search for information about their newborns is in the pre-dawn hours of the morning. As a result, Nestlé created a 24-hour digital platform to provide important tips and information for these new parents. This service allows them to digitally connect with mothers at a time when it would be difficult to connect through more traditional channels.

In the future, the traditional buy-sell model will become obsolete, as it will not be enough for retail and consumer companies to remain competitive. The future will be about the entire end-to-end experience. O2O, or online-to-offline, will only be one part of the value equation; the savviest of companies will manage the overall experience. Post-purchase services and service innovation, in particular, will be the way to extend the consumer experience beyond the point of purchase.

title: 40 - The Future of Manufacturing

insights.description: In the future, the absolute best in conversion technology will be used in manufacturing to reduce waste and carbon dioxide emissions. A high-quality workforce and high-tech operations will be key; people will have to be well trained.
Sustainability and contribution to society are becoming very important for companies in China.
The biggest challenge in manufacturing is not how to introduce robots into the workplace but how to train staff to work with robots.
China is by far the biggest robot market in the world in terms of annual sales and is the fastest-growing market worldwide (IFR, 2013)
Moving forward, the most successful countries will be the ones that can strike the right balance between technology, sustainability and lower cost. China has a big opportunity here.

description:
China and other emerging economies are investing heavily in research and development and rapidly increasing their high-technology output. Will the West soon be surpassed as the world's innovation powerhouse?

Join an interactive debate on the shifting centres of innovation, research and development.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is webcast live.<i>

name: Leading Global Innovation
title: 84 - Leading Global Innovation

insights.description: Internet access should be viewed as a resource like water, land or electricity. The right infrastructure could account for 30-40% of the cost of connecting as-yet-unconnected communities, and make connectivity more affordable.
The International Telecommunications Union is a natural home for the ambition of connecting the 4.4 billion people still without web access, because its role in the ecosystem is not biased.

The key to establishing internet access in remote areas is to get local developers and entrepreneurs to create their own content and have it distributed in a local setting – then build a successful use case from it.

In China, innovation is the first priority for 42% of Chinese companies, compared with 21% of MNCs, according to the 2014 China Innovation Study, which surveyed nearly 400 executives from Chinese and foreign companies. With a rising number of first-to-market innovations, China is building on its understanding of local markets and customer needs.

description:
With all economies and industries relying on the internet, the aim of this session is to explore how the resilience of the internet can be strengthened without strangling innovation.

On the agenda:
- Mobile applications 
- Digital commerce and platform business models
- Internet of things and emerging technologies 

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is webcast live.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Future-Proofing the Internet Economy
title: 46 - Future-Proofing the Internet Economy

insights.description: In the next 30 years, there will be 3 billion people born in the internet era. This will change the world in a tremendous way in the next 85 years.

Without technological innovation we have no hope of solving today’s problems. But the disruption it causes might not be comfortable for everyone. When new technology comes to market, there are issues about whether it’s good for society and whether it's good for existing business models. We need to ensure innovation is not stalled simply because it affects a business model.

In 2016, the digital economy will be worth more than $4 trillion – at least in the G20 economies. In order to expand beyond the G20 we need innovation in digital governance, not just in technology. This requires a multistakeholder approach.

Globalization has worked for multinationals that know how to function across borders, work with governments and build good solutions around the world, but it has not directly benefited small businesses. Innovative trade rules, combined with the power of the internet economy, could help small enterprises become global.

There is a fear that local cultures will be lost due to the global reach of the internet, and some governments are taking steps to counter this eventuality. But it’s not governments that build cultural values – it’s families, daily life and the internet. It’s possible to have global values that don’t eliminate local culture, but these are yet to be discovered.

description:

Session objectives:
- Map plausible futures for the Internet
- Explore implications for cybersecurity
- Develop strategic options for securing the digital enterprise

Join a collaborative scenario session on the World Economic Forum's Global Challenge Initiative on Future of the Internet.

title: 86 - Mapping Solutions: Securing the Digital Enterprise

insights.description: Governments need to provide incentives to encourage businesses to enhance their cybersecurity. These could include tax breaks for transparency and the maintenance of best cyber practices. A push could be a system based on cyber liability insurance; governments would issue a fine that rises each year depending on how the company performs in an annual audit.
The amount of encrypted traffic has increased dramatically in a post-Snowden world.
More policy-making should assume a hyper-transparent world within a zero trust environment.

description:
How will China adapt its growth strategy in the context of the "new normal"?

Dimensions to be addressed:
- Tackling equity market volatility, local debt and asset-bubble risks 
- Boosting innovation through grassroots entrepreneurship
- Balancing long-term structural reforms and short-term solutions

This session was developed in partnership with Caixin Media.

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>As this session is televised, please arrive 15 minutes early. The doors will be closed at the scheduled time. This session is webcast live.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: China's Reform Agenda
title: 3 - China's Reform Agenda

insights.description: The stock market is important up to a point in China. Market capitalization is only 40% of GDP compared with 140% of GDP in countries like the United States. The degree of importance is often overstated and most households don’t own shares.

China's consumption is growing about 8%-10% a year, with the internet world accounting for about half of that growth. This growth in consumption is not limited to big cities and the emerging middle class, but also in lower tier cities and in the upper middle class, which will experience growth in the double digits

To change something takes time, like the evolution of natural species. Not all SOEs can change overnight. It might be useful to have pilot projects. Enterprises need trial-and-error reform. We should not assume that the government will never change.

When government is the sole bearer of financial risk, it leads to speculation and over-investment. The implicit guarantee that the government will bail you out is a major systemic risk in China. There needs to be a re-evaluation of who benefits and who bears the cost to prevent future bubbles.

When the stock market is down and capital becomes more conservative, it does not imply there will be no innovation. After the bubble burst in Silicon Valley, the environment for innovation actually improved since capital became smarter and was used to fund better investments.

description:
Catalysing technological innovation in the traditional energy sector is critical in China’s transformation towards environmental sustainability.

Explore in the <i>Transformation Hub<i> how China can decarbonize its energy systems.

<i>Please arrive early, as space is limited.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Deep Dive: Decarbonizing Energy in China
title: 28 - Deep Dive: Decarbonizing Energy in China

insights.description: In China, long-term decarbonization targets and a slowing economy have already made a big impact on the coal sector. Smaller, less-efficient coal-fired power plants have been phased out. Capacity has been replaced with larger, cleaner-burning plants, which, if not already using carbon capture and storage technology, have the capacity built in.

By 2030, coal will still account for 50% of the energy mix in China, dropping to 30% by 2050. Today, coal makes up about 70% of the energy balance. China remains attached to coal largely for energy security reasons, having one of the world’s largest supplies of the resource. Unlike the United States, it has not been able to capitalize on the shale gas revolution.

In China there is a good amount of political certainty around long-term energy targets. The government has pledged that emissions will peak in 2030 and by then 20% of energy will come from renewable energy the majority of this being nuclear and hydro. However, many in the industry feel there is less specific information on the short-term targets, such as the price of carbon and the system by which it is regulated.

A number of China’s large energy companies have been making international acquisitions and becoming net exporters of capital and significant players in the global FDI landscape. This is, in part, spurred by slower domestic growth and a search for more robust returns abroad. However, many of the acquisitions are investments in new clean-energy technology.

Therefore, efficient electricity storage is the key missing link to establish sustainable electricity systems. It represents to electricity what refrigeration was for the food-supply chain.

title: 160 - The Innovation Outlook

insights.description: Innovation is enabling new types of collaboration, which in turn supports new forms of innovation. But this can only continue in an environment of trust. Government, business and individuals have a role in ensuring that innovation is applied in the right way.

5G will increase the response speed networks 50 fold compared to 4G, but it will require more open cooperation across industries and regulation support. A dialogue should be started across industries to define the standards of 5G together.

Technology innovation is usually a result of iteration and this same mindset should be applied to regulation approaches; replicating elements of the innovation process like experimentation, pilots and trials and learning from success and failure.

description:
Digital technologies are an important driver in China’s transformation into a consumer economy. 

Explore in the Transformation Hub how e-commerce is transforming China’s consumer industries. 

<i>Please arrive early, as space is limited in the Transformation Hub.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Deep Dive: China's E-Commerce Boom
title: 141 - Deep Dive: China's E-Commerce Boom

insights.description: The most successful consumer companies in China make a point of understanding its large, complicated market. For example, the white goods firm Haier segments its products by demographics and region. In the north of China, people tend to eat more meat and freeze it, so Haier sells refrigerators with a large freezer section; in the south, the diets consist of more vegetables so they market refrigerators with larger refrigerated sections. In urban areas, refrigerators are smaller for apartment living; and in rural areas where a refrigerator is a status symbol, they are as large as possible.

The luxury product market is significantly larger in second-tier Chinese cities than in first-tier cities, such as Beijing and Shanghai. High import taxes make these goods significantly cheaper abroad; consequently, affluent consumers from first-tier cities tend to leave the country to purchase high-value consumer goods.

Many foreign e-commerce companies have tried and failed to enter the Chinese market. For example, eBay entered China attempting to use the same model that had been successful in the US. Users would pay for goods and then wait to receive them. This model failed as it did not take into account the cultural specifics of China, namely a lack of trust between buyers and sellers. Taobao solved this problem by instituting a third-party payment system, releasing the money only when the product was received. These kinds of cultural specifics are a common barrier to entry for foreign e-commerce companies.

insights.description: In Europe, 80% of financing is through bilateral loans with banks, and 20% through alternative means of financing. In the US it is the opposite. Europe has very different capital: it is very local, and ways need to be found to create more access to alternative financing.

There is a disconnect between scientific opportunity – genomics, neuroscience, stem cell research – and the investments needed to speed up research. In the private sector, there seems to be less willingness to invest in projects that will not show a return on investment within a year or two.

The Accelerating Medicines Partnership programme focuses on a few areas including diabetes and arthritis. It is a partnership of the National Institute of Health (NIH), biotech start-ups and non-profits, which has been very successful because it is very focused – it has clear milestones, timetables, deliverables and go/ no-go decision points. This focused, detailed model is an effective way forward, rather than a diffuse idea of "working together".

insights.description: 30 years ago, China, a country that accounted for one-fifth of the world population, only contributed to 3% of global GDP; China now contributes to 14% of global GDP. Based on its population, however, China should be contributing 20%. To continue to drive the growth given a larger economic base, it is important to prioritize inclusive growth to narrow the gaps, and to further elevate the “institutional” structure of the society.

The Chinese economy is largely affected by the Hukou system, which not only indicates one’s residency rights, but also links individuals to social benefits. Hukou reform is moving to the right direction of social inclusion, but better policy at the central and local level is needed to close gaps.

insights.description: Historically, one of the biggest challenges in creating social change has been how to measure the changes in attitude that lead to changes in behaviour. But data science is opening up huge opportunities to measure changes in attitude via social media feeds.

Social science shows that a committed minority can create change among a more passive majority. The key is to determine the tipping point where the message can exist, independent of the original messenger.

description:
Humankind is at the threshold of a new industrial revolution driven by the confluence of a staggering range of emerging technologies. How will it transform politics, economies and societies?

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English, Mandarin Chinese and Japanese<i>

<i>This session is webcast live.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Navigating the Next Industrial Revolution
title: 94 - Navigating the Next Industrial Revolution

insights.description: Imagine broken bridges that repair themselves -- this is what our bodies do everyday. After blood, bone is the most transplanted material. Why not take the cells that grow bone and use them to make bone, rather than the traditional transplant approach? We are witnessing a confluence of technologies to design living systems through digital fabrication.

Often concerns over disruptive technologies are really grounded in values. Several debates about technologies ranging from fracking to genetically modified foods seem to be about technology, but they are really about values. The debates are made more complex by the fact that there are different value systems in different cultures.

Today we have the capability to do genome editing - to fix broken genes. Over 5,000 diseases are genetic-related. The cost of DNA sequences has plummeted over the past few years, while at the same time the accuracy has increased exponentially.

The impact of technology on employment will be profound. I expect the impact to be greater on doctors than on nurses. It will be safer to be employed as a plumber than as a management consultant. This is what's different about this technological revolution -- it will impact the higher paying jobs as much, if not more than, the lower paying jobs.
The largest share of tax revenue from most governments is related to labour. What if scarce raw materials were taxed rather than labour? Imagine the impact it would have on the planet's stewardship.

description:
How can the integration of traditional and modern medicine improve our health and well-being?

<i>Simultaneous interpretation in English and Mandarin Chinese<i>

<i>Please arrive early, as space is limited.<i>
programmeName: Official - Annual Meeting of the New Champions
name: Traditional Medicine: Bridging Past and Future
title: 13 - Traditional Medicine: Bridging Past and Future

insights.description: Knowledge that is handed down needs to be better respected. For example, it wasn’t until the 1980s that researchers in the West understood that an infant’s position while sleeping is an important factor in Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. Scientists used a massive, randomized control sample in researching the syndrome; meanwhile in China, every grandmother shared the knowledge that a baby must sleep on its back, and has done so for generations. In New Zealand, after the research pinpointed the cause, deaths from this syndrome fell by 80%.

Epidemiological studies are a cost effective way to identify multiple factors causing disease. Combining this with traditional knowledge and passed-down experience could result in better overall health outcomes. The judicious application of a standardized regime of traditional medicine (which takes a holistic approach) in combination with modern technology could result in better health for individuals, as Western medicine alone tends to treat only the symptoms, and not the cause of illness. This is particularly true in chronic conditions such as asthma.

Business leaders and politicians have a responsibility to promote healthy lifestyles to reduce the number of people suffering from lifestyle-related diseases. Commercializing the positive aspects of traditional medicine could help in this effort. The Chinese government is opening hospitals to private investment and encouraging them to diversify for the health and well-being of the population.

Standardizing practices and registering traditional practitioners would mean that people have more confidence in choosing to turn first to traditional medicine, especially before resorting to surgery. Hong Kong was highlighted as it has a registration system so traditional practitioners can only practice with a licence. India also has a successful model of combined traditional Ayurvedic and modern medical practices.
